title: 107_s930
content:
The "Grand Canyon Capital Improvements Act of 2001" includes sections on short title, definitions, fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, park surcharge or set-aside, use of bond proceeds, report, and regulations. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Fundraising organization - entity authorized under section 3(a).
Memorandum of agreement - agreement entered into by the Secretary under section 3(a) with terms specified in section 4.
Park - Grand Canyon National Park.
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary can make a memorandum of agreement with an entity to fundraise for the Grand Canyon National Park. The fundraising organization must issue taxable bonds in exchange for funds collected for the Park. They must adhere to professional standards and be audited by the Secretary. The United States is not liable for the bonds. Professional Standards require fundraising organizations to comply with securities laws and professional standards. The organization will be audited by the Secretary, and the United States is not liable for any bonds issued. SEC. 4. MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue amount, bond maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, reserve requirements, funded projects at the Park, and procedures for agreement modifications. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue amount, maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita repayment amount, reserve requirements, funded projects at the Park, and procedures for agreement modifications based on changing circumstances. SEC. 5. PARK SURCHARGE OR SET-ASIDE. The Secretary may authorize the Superintendent of the Park to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts. The Park may charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts. This surcharge is separate from any entrance fees collected under other programs or initiatives. The Park may charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts, as mandated by section 315 of the Department of the Interior and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1996 and the national park passport program. The surcharge must be used by the fundraising organization to amortize the bond issue. The Park may charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under specific acts. The surcharge must be used by the fundraising organization to amortize the bond issue, cover administration costs, and maintain a reserve as determined by the bond underwriter. SEC. 6. USE OF BOND PROCEEDS. Bond proceeds under this Act can be used for projects in the Park, subject to certain limitations and prohibitions on administrative use. The bond proceeds can be used for projects in the Park, following laws and the general management plan. No part of the proceeds can be used for administrative expenses, except for interest which can cover reserve requirements and reasonable administrative expenses. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of regulations being issued, reviewing the bond program at the Park and providing recommendations on establishing a bond program at all National Park units. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will promulgate regulations to implement the Act.
